Reads the table FloReporting.report.FloRunAnalysisReport for the given RunId.

The main purpose of the report is to give insight on why the benchmark algorithm didnâ€™t give discount decisions to items in a run. The IsValid columns give info on if the status of a condition allows the algoritm to give a discount decision. The rest of the columns are to give numerical information of the items status.

This report makes it easy to quickly analyze runs both for the customer and for us.

To filter for multiple ItemCodeâ€™s (up to 8) enter the desired ItemCodeâ€™s separated by a comma and select True from the Show All Items filter. This will show the selected items only.

d by a comma and select True from the Show All Items filter. This will show the selected items only.

If the report fails to give results for a run that is completed, the SP might have given an error. Check if the run executed properly and if there are no problems with the run analyze the SP itself. Refer to [[report].[RunAnalysisReport]] for detailed information on the SP logic.

## Contents

1. Case Example: Mavi Airflow Transition
2. Airflow, Github, and S3: How are code in the repository being used in Airflow DAGs?
3. How to understand where the source code is stored in S3 &Â  Airflow DAG steps are reading the desired source code

## Case Example: Mavi Airflow Transition

We recently experienced a case in the customer Mavi during our transition to a new airflow structure. The transition caused a complication: DAGs were running on an old source code and we could not see our most recent developments in enrich, forecast train data, forecast test data e.t.c.

We made developments & iteratively ran DAG steps on a cluster to check if things are working correctly, which is explained in this how-to documentation.

## Airflow, Github, and S3: How are code in the repository being used in Airflow DAGs?

metadata.title: Markdown: How to check if DAGs are sourced by correct Python scripts and config files

content:
cumentation.

## Airflow, Github, and S3: How are code in the repository being used in Airflow DAGs?

- Each Jenkins build also updates the source code and config files stored in S3 with the latest source repository.Â This means that if your pull request is recently merged on Github you also need to run a Jenkins build in master branch to deploy the source code to S3.

- Airflow DAGs use the source code, config, and parquet files stored in S3. However, they might be reading a path other than the path that Jenkins builds update.I.e. in Mavi case, Jenkins build was overwriting the source code stored in s3/invent-mavi-datastore/src while the Airflow was reading the source code from s3/invent-mavi-datastore/src/prod

## How to understand where the source code is stored in S3 & Airflow DAG steps are reading the desired source code

metadata.title: Markdown: How to check if DAGs are sourced by correct Python scripts and config files

content:
rstand where the source code is stored in S3 & Airflow DAG steps are reading the desired source code

- You need to look under folders in S3 such as invent-<<customer>>-datastore/src until you find a documentation similar to Github repository structure.
- When you find the .py documents inside the folder, check if they have the same code with the most updated version of master branch in Github.
- If the code is not the same, you can backup & erase the .py documents and try to run the related DAG steps.If the DAG fails, you need to talk with CX-IT or Alpha to make sure the source code is deployed from the correct branch in the Github repository.If the DAG does not fail but you still see that an old version of the repository is functioning, there is a high probability that the DAG is reading a document stored at a different directory. You can ask for help from Alpha to find the path that the DAG is currently reading from.

- markdown.MarkdownSeasons - This table contains Season information such as SeasonCode, SeasonType, StartDate, and EndDate. It is updated manually.
- markdown.ActiveSeasons - Idâ€™s of active seasons are stored in this table. The table is updated manually, you need to insert the new SeasonId while deleting the unnecessary SeasonIds.
- markdown.ParentSeasonRelationships - This tables connects SeasonIdâ€™s in core tables such as data.InventoryPosition & data.WarehouseInventoryPosition (sourced from model.Seasons) with the Seasons stored in markdown.Seasons. SeasonId in markdown.Seasons is considered as ParentSeasonId in markdown.ParentSeasonRelationships. It is updated manually.
- markdown.PriceSteps - This table contains default PriceSteps for each SeasonId, StoreCluster, and ProductGroup combination. This table is also updated manually. Generally you can clone this table for the season by using previous seasonâ€™s PriceSteps.

d manually. Generally you can clone this table for the season by using previous seasonâ€™s PriceSteps.
- markdown.ItemPriceSteps - This table contains price steps for each ItemCode and StoreCluster combination. It is updated with forecast_preparation DAG on a daily basis.
- markdown.ItemSeasonHistory - This table contains season start date for each ItemCode and StoreCluster combination.
- markdown.ItemEntryDates - This table contains market entry dates for each ItemCode and StoreCluster combination.  It is updated with forecast_preparation DAG on a daily basis.

- Previous Week vs Current Week: How did the sales trend change within the last two weeks? We control this both item based and on an aggregate level.
- Actual vs Projection: How different are our predictions from actual sales amounts? Did we overestimate or underestimate? We control this both item based and on an aggregate level.
- Previous Week vs Projection: Do our predictions make sense when compared with the last week? We control this both item based and on an aggregate level.
- Last 4 Weekâ€™s Sales, Price, Stocksâ€¦: Do our predictions make sense when compared with the last 4 weeks KPIs? We mainly control this item-based, when analyzing and commenting on poor performing items.

eks KPIs? We mainly control this item-based, when analyzing and commenting on poor performing items.
- Discount vs No Discount Performance: Do our prediction performance differ between discounted products and products with no discount? We control this both item based and on an aggregate level. This section is particularly important for us to understand our forecasted elasticities (i.e. How much the price of an item changes when there is a price change.)
- Discount Steps: Did we successfully predict the price elasticities? Just like the discount vs no discount items, this topic helps us to understand price elasticities. The difference is we also compare price change volumes here (i.e. 20% price difference differs from 50% price difference. We might be giving too much sales increase to a 50% discounted group or too little sales increase to a 20% discounted group.)

ch sales increase to a 50% discounted group or too little sales increase to a 20% discounted group.)
- Hierarchies: Do our predictions differ between certain product groups? This section is important for us to understand whether we are accurately predicting seasonality or not. (i.e. we expect lower elasticity and sales volume for jackets during summer period.)

In order to successfully evaluate the performance of our runs we conduct analysis in these categories and compare our run results. This comparison can be needed for several reasons:

- Client Update: How accurate were our predictions last month? Did we improve our prediction performance?Â  (Current Accuracy Run vs Last Month Accuracy Run) Clients ask for accuracy run analyses in order to give feedback to our predictions and create a room for improvement on our forecasting and optimization models.
- New Feature Engineering: How did our new feature affect the performance of our runs? (Accuracy Run w.o. the New Feature vs Accuracy Run with the New Feature) When we identify a room for improvement and develop a new feature, we test the new feature before going live. We compare different accuracy runs by training two different models: With and without the new feature.
- Comparisons with Previous Season: How accurate were our predictions for this sales campaign this year? How different were our predictions last year? (Accuracy Run of Last Season vs Accuracy Run of this Season)

fferent were our predictions last year? (Accuracy Run of Last Season vs Accuracy Run of this Season)

## Analysis Metrics

### Tableau Dashboard

We use the FC Accuracy Projected report to analyze accuracy runs in the UI. The clients also use this report when analyzing the accuracy runs we share with them. This report can be an alternative & safer way to do the initial analyses of an accuracy run.

When we need to deep dive, we conduct our accuracy run analysis by gathering the following data together:

we need to deep dive, we conduct our accuracy run analysis by gathering the following data together:

- Actual Sales Quantity (markdown.WeeklyPastData)
- Projected Sales Quantity (markdown.WeeklyProjection)
- Previous Week Sales Quantity (markdown.RecentOptimizationParameters)
- Actual DiscountÂ (Calculate using markdown.ItemPriceHistory & markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory)
- Projected Discount (markdown.WeeklyProjection)
- Last Week Discount (markdown.RecentOptimizationParameters)
- Last 4 Weeks' Sales, Stock, Price Metrics (markdown.WeeklyPastData)
- Product Descriptions: Hierarchies, Brand, Age, Size Countâ€¦ (markdown.ItemInformationCache)
- Brokennes (Size Count x Max. Store Count) (Store Count can also be found in WeeklyPastData)

## MAPE & Bias

We measure our run performances with two main metrics:

- MAPE: ABS(Actual Sales- Predicted Sales) / Actual Sales
- Bias: (Actual Sales- Predicted Sales) / Actual Sales

Actual Sales- Predicted Sales) / Actual Sales
- Bias: (Actual Sales- Predicted Sales) / Actual Sales

Our quality benchmark values for these metrics are like the following. Anything below these metrics can be considered good and anything above these metrics mean that we need to work on improvements:

- MAPE: 40%
- Bias: 10%

SELECT WPD.ItemCode, WeekStartDate, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3,
       WP.WeekDiscountRate AS DiscountRate,
       ROP.PreviousDiscountRate AS PreviousDiscountRate,
       ROP.PreviousWeekSales AS PreviousWeekSales,
       WPD.Sales AS ActualSales,
       WP.Sales  AS ProjectedSales
FROM MaviV3.markdown.WeeklyPastData WPD
INNER JOIN markdown.ItemInformationCache IIC ON WPD.ItemCode = IIC.ItemCode
                                         AND WPD.StoreCluster = IIC.StoreCluster
                                         AND IIC.SeasonId = 50
INNER JOIN markdown.RecentOptimizationParameters ROP ON ROP.RunId = 57706
                                                            AND ROP.ItemCode = WPD.ItemCode
                                                            AND ROP.StoreCluster = WPD.StoreCluster
LEFT JOIN markdown.WeeklyProjection WP ON WPD.ItemCode = WP. ItemCode
                                        AND WPD.StoreCluster = WP.StoreCluster

emCode = WP. ItemCode
                                        AND WPD.StoreCluster = WP.StoreCluster
                                        AND WPD.WeekStartDate = WP.WeekStart
WHERE WP.RunId = 57706
AND WP.ProjectionType = 0
--AND WeekStartDate = '2025-01-01'
ORDER BY ItemCode, WeekStartDate

```

#### Related Tables (Check Data Dictionary if you are looking for other variables)

[ClientDatabase].markdown.ItemPriceHistory - Gather item prices from realized sales.

[ClientDatabase].markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory - Gather initial item prices without any discount.

[ClientDatabase].markdown.ItemInformationCache - Gather descriptive item information such as H1, H2, H3, Brand e.t.c.

[ClientDatabase].markdown.WeeklyPastData - Gather actual sales and discount information.

[ClientDatabase].markdown.WeeklyProjection - Gather projected sales and discount information.

[ClientDatabase].markdown.RecentOptimizationParameters - Gather sales and discount information for the previous week.

This document describes the steps for adding a new feature to the forecast model. The following example will consist of adding a feature to the Mavi E-com model. Since the retail model works well enough additional features or accuracy improvements are not needed at the moment. The feature added in the example is present in both the Retail and ECOM data however it is designed to be the same for all retail data which means it doesnâ€™t increase or decrease accuracy for retail predictions.

content: - Define the Problem & HypothesisIdentify the issue or opportunity that the new feature aims to address.The current feature set was not good enough for predicting E-com sales at campaign dates and the model had the tendency to give forecast that were way under the actual sales. For example the new feature (day_effect) is aimed to help the model learn the effect of specific days sales volume on actual sales to improve accuracy.Formulate a hypothesis about how the feature could improve forecast accuracy.Each day has different sales which we can infer from the day effect of the given day. This day effect can be calculated from past sales and is thought to produce variety in data. If added to the model it could improve accuracy.

content: - Collect & Prepare DataGather relevant data for the new feature.Since the day effect is already calculated, there is no need to gather new data. However, a different improvement could need new data or maybe altering the existing data. For the day_effect calculation, we altered the original table from S3 storage named markdown_weekly_ecom_campaigns and added a new column called campaign_start_date to get the index of the start date.Clean, preprocess, and engineer the data (e.g., handling missing values, normalizing, or encoding).For the new feature to be effective, data needs to be prepared in a way that reflects reality. The day_effect is calculated but another improvement, marketplace-ecom separation, might need proper preprocessing of the data. For example, the original data for the ecom separation didnâ€™t take into account returns which is not the reality so you need to be careful when preparing the data

metadata.title: Adding a New Feature To Forecast Model

content:
take into account returns which is not the reality so you need to be careful when preparing the data. See Noob Forecast Improvements for more info.Ensure alignment with existing features (time granularity, format, etc.)This step is simple but important. If time indexes are not aligned, the data will be wrong. For example for the day_effect feature, the indexes of each day are different in the database and pyspark. If indexes are not adjusted correctly, day_effect values of each day will be wrong.

content: - Add The Feature To The Model And Test For ErrorsDecide which step you want the new feature to be calculated or added in.This step is important as you may not be able to calculate certain features in different steps of forecast. For the day_effect feature, there was already a join being made with the related file in enrich step so we added the column on enrich. However, for the marketplace separation we had to adjust both enrich and forecast data prep steps so it is important to inspect the files.Always work on a cluster first to not mess up the files and data in production.Make sure to make your changes by copying the github code to a cluster and execute after additions or removals

metadata.title: Adding a New Feature To Forecast Model

content:
to make your changes by copying the github code to a cluster and execute after additions or removals. You need to either adjust the config and change the default config path or donâ€™t execute the run step but manually run the preprocess, main and postprocess steps to ensure it doesnâ€™t change the files in S3.The cluster memory or speed might not be able to execute enrich.main() step so you might need to try and join the tables and do calculations manually in the cluster to see if it works properly.
- Analyze Accuracy By Getting Test RunsCreate a test environment in S3 and save a new config file with adjusted paths for the new test environment.Save the results to the new environment and get test runs for accuracy analysis.Check if there is an improvement in MAPE and Bias metrics. If certain hierarchies have different results you might want to adjust so the feature is filled only for the groups which had positive outcomes from the feature.

content:
This document explains how to debug the run results from different aspects.

The run analysis primarily focuses on products that are either:

- Outside the model scope,
- Included in the scope but yield infeasible results due to optimization constraints,
- Identified as unsuitable for the applied markdown decisions. (Undesired output control)

We will examine these scenarios step by step.

## Phase  : High-Level Overview

Before diving into details, the WeeklyOptimizationResults report available in the UI (under Reports section in Markdown region) provides an excellent way to grasp the bigger picture.

- WeeklyOptimizationResults Report in the UI -

UI - WeeklyOptimizationResults:

- Check sales and markdown loss at an aggregate level.
- Explore hierarchies for additional comparisons.

eck sales and markdown loss at an aggregate level.
- Explore hierarchies for additional comparisons.

#### Case Possibilities to Observe:For the details about controlling run KPIs you can view: https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CMP/pages/4985520166/Markdown+Operation+Run+Analysis?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiN2IyOWIzZDBlZjY2NDE3MDgwNTM3ZDRjNTEwZTJkNWYiLCJwIjoiYyJ9

- Sales Quantity is too low: There might be too many missing items or a missing target group.There might be too few discounted items.
- Sales Quantity & Markdown Loss is too high:There might be too many discounted items.
- Markdown Loss is too low for the campaign week:There might be too few discounted items.
- Campaigns do not appear in the report:The campaign might not have been added to markdown.Promotions.

## Phase  : Analyzing Items Outside Model Scope

n might not have been added to markdown.Promotions.

## Phase  : Analyzing Items Outside Model Scope

The next step is to analyze products included in the target group (provided by the customer) but missing from the final run output. These products were not included in the model's scope. The `markdown.RemovedItems` table can be used to investigate the reasons.

This table lists excluded items along with labels indicating the reason for removal. Checks to perform:

- No stock available for the item:

> Note: Donâ€™t forget to check AddCurrentPriceToValidPriceSteps and AddFirstPriceToValidPriceSteps parameters from engine.RunParameterDefaults. If the AddCurrentPriceToValidPriceSteps and AddFirstPriceToValidPriceSteps parameters are enabled, both prices are included in the Gurobi solver during the optimization process. Normally, if these items lack a valid forecast for their existing price in markdown.ExternalForecasts, they would result in an infeasible solution. These parameters help prevent that.However, if no forecast exists for an item's current price, a linearized forecast is used instead, which can lead to unreliable results.

Calculate sales projection for discounted & non-discounted scenarios.

SELECT
    wp01.RunId,
    wp01.ItemCode,
    wp01.StoreCluster,
    SUM(CASE WHEN ProjectionType = 1 THEN wp01.Sales ELSE 0 END) AS Sales_Projection_1,
    SUM(CASE WHEN ProjectionType = 0 THEN wp01.Sales ELSE 0 END) AS Sales_Projection_0
INTO #WP
FROM FibaDelta.markdown.WeeklyProjection AS wp01
WHERE RunId = @RunId
GROUP BY wp01.RunId, wp01.ItemCode, wp01.StoreCluster

SELECT (rop.TotalSalesInSeason * 1.0) / NULLIF((rop.TotalSalesInSeason + rop.ForecastStartStock), 0)  AS CurrentST,
       ((rop.TotalSalesInSeason * 1.0) + Sales_Projection_0)/ NULLIF((rop.TotalSalesInSeason + rop.ForecastStartStock), 0)  AS ST_Projection_0,
       ((rop.TotalSalesInSeason * 1.0) + Sales_Projection_1)/ NULLIF((rop.TotalSalesInSeason + rop.ForecastStartStock), 0)  AS ST_Projection_1
INTO #Calculations
FROM #RecentOptimizationParameters rop

> Info: If the target group is created via UI filtering item code, store cluster and  season filters   , you can configure ST targets for the weeks listed in the calendar at the target group level. However, you cannot differentiate ST targets at the item level.

> Info: You can update ST targets in the database for items that belong to the same target group under markdown.ScenarioItemParameters

in the database for items that belong to the same target group under markdown.ScenarioItemParameters

> Note: When making this update, pay attention to items that exist in DefaultItemParameters but not in ScenarioItemParameters. Since markdown.RecentOptimizationParameters will look for these items in markdown.ScenarioItemParameters first and, if not found, will revert to markdown.DefaultItemParameters, the old ST values will be used for these items.To avoid this, you may prefer to first add these items to ScenarioItemParameters for each scenario and then proceed with updating the ST targets.

A configuration or config file is used to store information that can be accessed by any module or file that has access to the file. It is usually in JSON format and is similar to a Python dictionary object. The file stores key-value pairs where each key is unique and is associated with a value. The Markdown Hub is not responsible for creating or maintaining these config files but if there is a feature addition or testing needs to be done, it may need some adjustments. The main config file this document takes into account is the noob config which is used in forecasting modules.

The noob config file is composed of two main parts. The first part is the default values such as bucket_name or noob_home etc. These indicate the default values a module should take.

metadata.title: Noob Config Adjustment For Forecast Improvements

content:
values such as bucket_name or noob_home etc. These indicate the default values a module should take.

```json
"Default": {
    "file_schema": "s3://",
    "bucket_name": "invent-mavi-datastore",
    "noob_home": "noob",
    "operation_home": "operation",
    "master_data_home": "master-data",
    "metadata_path": "metadata",
    "io_control_path": "io-control",
    "week_start_day": 3,
    "metadata": {}
```

For example, the week_start_day is constant and is wednesday for Mavi which is why it has the value 3 in the config. You will most likely never change this part except for the metadata. Metadata is where you specify a new file path for a module. If there is nothing in metadata for the given module it will use the default path.

The second part is module specific values. Each module (Enrich, Forecast Data Preparation, Forecasting etc.) has its own variables and constants. Below, enrich is shown.

metadata.title: Noob Config Adjustment For Forecast Improvements

content:
ast Data Preparation, Forecasting etc.) has its own variables and constants. Below, enrich is shown.

```json
  "markdown_enrich": {
    "start_date": "2021-02-01",
    "current_season_id": "SS25",
    "forecast_horizon": 210,
    "weekly_data_path": "markdown_weekly_data",
    "forecast_scope_path": "markdown_fc_scope",
    "output_path": "markdown-enrich",
    "items_path": "markdown_items",
    "markdown_weekly_ecom_campaign_path": "markdown_weekly_ecom_campaigns",

```

Here you can see the path variables that enrich module uses to read and write data. The default output path is `"output_path": "markdown-enrich"`. Here is where metadata comes in, if a variable is specified in metadata, it will override the module specific variable and its value. If you are working in jupyter notebook and donâ€™t want to override the current data in S3, you will need to change the metadata.

metadata.title: Noob Config Adjustment For Forecast Improvements
Noob Config Adjustment For Forecast Improvements

content:
import os
os.environ["NOOB_CONFIG_PATH"] = "s3://invent-mavi-datastore/jupyter/user/config.json"
```

Make sure to run this code before you execute any other module so it can take effect.

Another change you can make on the config file is adding or removing specific columns to specific operations. For example you can change the scope of the I/O Control module that runs after forecasting step. The default is shown below:

```json
  "markdown_long_term_forecast": {
    "io_control_level": [
      "item_code",
      "store_cluster"
    ],
  }
```

If you want to add another layer to the control you can add the specific column name. A use case for this can be found in [Noob Forecast Improvements].

metadata.title: Noob Config Adjustment For Forecast Improvements

content:
can add the specific column name. A use case for this can be found in [Noob Forecast Improvements].

Other changes include adding a new feature column to the features under markdown_long_term_forecast. If you want the new feature to be used in training and predicting with the model, you will need to add the column based on its data type. For example if the data type is integer or float you need to add it to numerical_cols or if is it a string than you need to add it to categorical_cols.

```json
"markdown_long_term_forecast": {
  "features": {
      "numerical_cols": [
        "total_purchased",
         ...
        "new_feature_numerical"
      ],
      "categorical_cols": [
        "base_md_percentage_last_week",
         ...
        "new_featurecategorical"
      ],
      "other_cols": [
        "base_md_percentage",
         ...
        "new_feature_other"
      ],
      "cat_type": "ordinal"
    }
  }
```

metadata.title: Noob Config Adjustment For Forecast Improvements

content:
## Overview

The following document describes how we analyze the performance of Markdown operation runs. In order to do a comprehensive analysis of run performances we conduct several comparisons:

- Previous Week vs Projection: Does our forecast make sense when compared with last weeksâ€™ data?
- Last 4/8 Weeks: Does our forecast make sense when compared with the last weeksâ€™ performance?
- MD Loss & Sales Jump: Do our prediction performance differ between discounted products and products with no discount? Do price elasticities in our forecasts align with the past elasticity values?
- Hierarchies: Do our predictions differ between certain product groups, genders etc?

An overview of operation run can be controlled using the UI Report - Weekly Optimization Results. For details we typically use SQL Queries.

*- Weekly Optimization Results Report in the UI -*

## Analysis Metrics

We conduct our operation run analysis by gathering the following data together:

## Analysis Metrics

We conduct our operation run analysis by gathering the following data together:

- SalesProjected Sales: How did we project sales performance? (markdown.WeeklyProjection)Actual Sales: How was the sales performance in previous weeks? (markdown.WeeklyPastData)
- Discount Rate (Markdown Loss, MD Loss)Projected Discount: How many items received a discount? How much? (markdown.WeeklyProjection)Actual Discount: How were discount rates of items in previous weeks? ( 1- (CurrentPrice / FirstPrice), using the latest entry in markdown.ItemPriceHistory for each item and markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory)
- Product Details (markdown.ItemInformationCache)ItemCodeBrandH1H2H3
- Price Information: Used for revenue & Markdown Loss calculations.Initial Price (markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory)Recent Price & Previous Price Updates (markdown.ItemPriceHistory)

ce (markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory)Recent Price & Previous Price Updates (markdown.ItemPriceHistory)

```sql
-- GATHER ITEM PRICES
SELECT *, LEAD(StartDate,1,'2099-01-01') OVER (PARTITION BY ItemCode ORDER BY StartDate) AS Valid
INTO #ItemPrices
FROM markdown.ItemPriceHistory

-- GATHER ITEM FIRST PRICES
SELECT *, LEAD(StartDate,1,'2099-01-01') OVER (PARTITION BY ItemCode ORDER BY StartDate) AS Valid
INTO #ItemFirstPrices
FROM markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory

--WEEKLYPASTDATA EXTRACT

SELECT wp.ItemCode, iic.H1, iic.H2, iic.H3,
       wp.WeekStart,
       wp.Sales AS ProjectedSales,
       wpd.Sales AS ActualSales,
       wpd.SalesRevenue AS SalesRevenue,
       wp.Sales * wp.WeekPrice AS ProjectedRevenue,
       wpd.StoreStock + wpd.StoreIncomingStock + wpd.WarehouseStock AS TotalStock,
       wp.WeekDiscountRate AS ProjectedDiscount,
       ROUND(1-ip.Price/ifp.Price,3) AS ActualDiscount,
       rop.PreviousDiscountRate AS PreviousDiscount
FROM markdown.WeeklyProjection wp
INNER JOIN #weeklypastdata wpd ON wpd.ItemCode = wp.ItemCode
                               AND wpd.StoreCluster = wp.StoreCluster
                               AND wpd.WeekStartDate = wp.WeekStart
INNER JOIN markdown.ItemInformationCache iic ON iic.ItemCode = wp.ItemCode
                                                    AND iic.StoreCluster = wp.StoreCluster
                                                    AND iic.SeasonId = 50

eCluster = wp.StoreCluster
                                                    AND iic.SeasonId = 50
INNER JOIN markdown.RecentOptimizationParameters rop ON rop.ItemCode = wp.ItemCode
                                                            AND rop.RunId = wp.RunId
                                                            AND rop.StoreCluster = wp.StoreCluster
INNER JOIN
    #ItemPrices ip
        ON ip.ItemCode = iic.ItemCode AND
           ip.StartDate <= wp.WeekStart AND
           ip.Valid > wp.WeekStart
INNER JOIN
    #ItemFirstPrices ifp
     ON ifp.ItemCode = iic.ItemCode
     AND ifp.StartDate <= wp.WeekStart
     AND ifp.Valid > wp.WeekStart
WHERE wp.RunId = 56323
  AND wp.ProjectionType = 0
  AND iic.Property1 = '00 Seri'
```

## Forecast Comparison Periods

We measure our operation run performances by comparing KPIs between these periods:

mparison Periods

We measure our operation run performances by comparing KPIs between these periods:

- Forecast: We calculate markdown KPIs for our forecasts to compare with the past data.(i.e. Same campaign last year, latest campaign in current season, sales trend of last 4-8 weeksâ€¦)
- Prediction Period: We consider the last 6 months prior to our forecast as the â€œprediction periodâ€. We expect an alignment or gradual transition between our forecasts and the prediction period. (i.e. if our forecast is between 01/2024 - 06/2024 then our prediction period is 06/2023 - 12/2023.)
- Like-for-like (LLY): We calculate the KPIs for the same time period in past years. (i.e. if our forecast is between 01/2024 - 06/2024 we can compare KPIs with 01/2023 - 06/2023 or 01/2022 - 06/2022.)

## Overview

This document explains how to check data uploaded by the customer and the modifications it goes through to spot any irregularities over a case study done for Mavi. If the regular markdown flow is disrupted and the reason is found to be the data, you might want to check the raw data to see if that is the source of the problem. If the raw data is wrong then it is not on the consultants and the customer is responsible for correcting their mistake. If the problem is not at the raw data but at one of the steps inside the daily flow then further debugging should be done.

## Steps

metadata.title: How To Check Data Uploaded By Customer

content:
1. Determine the problemThe problem may not always be related to raw data sent by the customer.Always make the preliminary checks in the database to ensure there is a problem.After determining the problem make sure to check simple cases first. For example, if there is no result for an item it might be getting removed before the optimization or it might not have an active calendar for the desired date etc.
2. Download and get access to Azure Storage Or Amazon S3 for the desired customerMake sure to correctly identify the bucket/blob/folder that the raw data is stored in.
3. Download the file and do a simple examinationUse excel for basic filtering to avoid using computation power with clusters or waste time waiting for clusters to start.If needed use python or other tools to check whether the raw data is problematic or not.

metadata.title: How To Check Data Uploaded By Customer

content:
rs to start.If needed use python or other tools to check whether the raw data is problematic or not.
4. Check the operation folder for the data you are looking forIf the data is not there then it is lost along the pipeline, check the pipeline to see where it went wrong.If the data is there inspect using python and check for desired aspects.
5. Check the databaseIf there are no problems up to this step, the problem may be related to an SP inside the database.Check which stored procedures are executed when the problem occurs.Try to run these stored procedures on a local file without altering the real tables to see where the data is lost.

## Example Case

metadata.title: How To Check Data Uploaded By Customer

content:
res on a local file without altering the real tables to see where the data is lost.

## Example Case

The first step in checking the raw data is finding the data. Each customer uploads necessary files for Invent to use daily. The content and name of each file is different for each customer so you will need to find the necessary file(s) you will be investigating. These files are stored either in Azure storage blobs or Amazon S3  buckets. To download and login to Amazon S3 please refer to [Aws Cli and S3 Browser Installation]. Remember to request access to the desired customers' Amazon S3 buckets or Azure blobs before starting.

You can check the necessary files for each solution from [Data Format UI](https://data-requirement-ui.k8s.inventanalytics.com/). Here you can see which files are needed for which solutions and their format such as columns, names etc. Keep in mind that accessing the Data Format UI requires an active Invent VPN connection.

metadata.title: How To Check Data Uploaded By Customer

content:
names etc. Keep in mind that accessing the Data Format UI requires an active Invent VPN connection.

After opening S3 or Azure you should find the desired customer, we will take Mavi as an example for this article. The problem with Mavi was that there were missing price history for certain items and this lead to these items becoming infeasible during the optimization step. Normally a few items coming up infeasible is fine but having large amounts of infeasible items, like in this case, is not desired and can result in the customer complaining. After doing basic checks on the database, we couldnâ€™t find the reason why there were no price history so we decided to check the source of the data and track its path to find where it was messed up.

metadata.title: How To Check Data Uploaded By Customer

content:
ory so we decided to check the source of the data and track its path to find where it was messed up.

First step was to find where the raw files were stored. You can try and guess by the names if you know the customer a bit or can just ask other consultants for the answer. If you are in a hurry and no one is there you can inspect the content of each bucket and the folders/files inside. For our case, the raw files which the customer uploads are in S3 invent-mavi-sap bucket. Here you can see that there are multiple files each named with the date they were uploaded on.

metadata.title: How To Check Data Uploaded By Customer

content:
cket. Here you can see that there are multiple files each named with the date they were uploaded on.

Price history data is usually uploaded before a season change so we looked for the folders uploaded before 2025-02-05. Inside a folder, there are multiple csv files which may not always follow the naming conventions, especially for older customers like Mavi. This was the case here so we had to manually inspect the files we thought were related to price buy guessing from their names. However, if you ask on Slack, someone will probably tell you which is which.

metadata.title: How To Check Data Uploaded By Customer

content:
ssing from their names. However, if you ask on Slack, someone will probably tell you which is which.

After finding the files, you can either download and inspect them manually on your local computer or you can use python to analyze the files in detail. In our case, doing simple CTRL + F searches to check for items and dates were enough. The content of this file includes the price points of each item at given dates. If a date is missing from this file, it will cause the price history to be empty like in our case. However, after checking the items and dates it was obvious there were no missing prices.

metadata.title: How To Check Data Uploaded By Customer

content:
n our case. However, after checking the items and dates it was obvious there were no missing prices.

The next part to check is the operation file in the datastore bucket, invent-mavi-datastore. The input files go through the ETL pipeline and get modified into usable states. These usable files are then written into the operation folder inside the datastore bucket under a name similar to the database. For example, price history is written into invent-mavi-datastore/operation/item_price_history/ folder.  The modified folder includes partitioned parquet files so you need to inspect them with python. After the operation folder you need to check if the data is undergoing any other procedures in the database or in the workflow scripts. In our case the problem was not about the raw data but in an SP in the database. This SP included a filter which filtered out some items due to a problem with entry dates. The problem was fixed afterwards.

content:
## ðŸŽ¯ 1. Purpose and Scope

This document explains the structure, logic, and usage of the Compliance Report designed to track how well customer-side implementations align with Inventâ€™s pricing decisions.

The goal is to evaluate:

- Whether Invent's discount decisions are being executed (Discount Compliance)
- Whether stores have matched Invent's recommended prices (Price Compliance)

The report provides metrics that show the level of execution fidelity for each markdown run, and it stores detailed, item-level insights.

## ðŸ” 2. Structure, Flow and Automation

The system consists of three main stored procedures:

`report.CreateComplianceReport`: Performs the core compliance calculation for a given RunId. Writes results into `RunItemComplResults` â€” an item-level results table that feeds the Tableau dashboard used for monitoring compliance metrics.

xxxxx SQL xxxxx  xxxxx SQL xxxxx

eeds the Tableau dashboard used for monitoring compliance metrics.

xxxxx SQL xxxxx  xxxxx SQL xxxxx

âœ… Triggered by: `report.ProcessEligibleComplianceRuns` (executed in `[etl].[RefreshMarkdownTables]` which works daily)

`report.TrackComplianceRun`: Identifies which RunIds are eligible for compliance evaluation based on a 3-week delay policy. Writes eligible runs to `report.PendingComplianceRuns`.

xxxxx SQL xxxxx  xxxxx SQL xxxxx

âœ… Triggered by: `[markdown].[RunPostProcessQueries]` (executed automatically after each markdown run completes):

```
CREATE PROCEDURE [markdown].[RunPostProcessQueries] (@RunId INT = 0)
AS
BEGIN
    EXEC [report].[RefreshRunReports] @RunId = @RunId;
    EXEC [report].[BenchmarkReport] @RunId = @RunId;
    EXEC [FibaReporting].[report].[CreateRunAnalysisReport] @RunId = @RunId;
    -- Do not run compliance immediately, just track it
    EXEC [FibaReporting].[report].[TrackComplianceRun] @RunId = @RunId;
END
```

    EXEC [FibaReporting].[report].[TrackComplianceRun] @RunId = @RunId;
END
```

`report.ProcessEligibleComplianceRuns:` Picks all RunIds from` PendingComplianceRuns`, runs the compliance analysis using `CreateComplianceReport`, and removes the processed entries.

xxxxx SQL xxxxx  xxxxx SQL xxxxx

âœ… Triggered by: `[etl].[RefreshMarkdownTables]` (executed daily):

```
EXEC FibaReporting.report.ProcessEligibleComplianceRuns;
```

> Info: This ensures:Every day, the system checks which runs are now eligible.Only runs with 3 weeks passed since ForecastStartDate are evaluated.Each run is processed only once thanks to the PendingComplianceRuns mechanism.Compliance analysis is delayed appropriately, with no premature execution.

## â³ 3. Time Window Logic â€“ Why 3 Weeks?

When Invent recommends a price during a markdown run, that price is typically implemented by client within 1â€“2 weeks. However, to ensure the recommendation had a fair chance to be applied:

d by client within 1â€“2 weeks. However, to ensure the recommendation had a fair chance to be applied:

- We introduce a 3-week delay between the run date and compliance evaluation.
- This ensures we capture price changes that may occur with delay due to operational or business-wise issues.

### ðŸ“… Example:

If forecast date of  a run starts on 03-09-2025(w11) we only evaluate compliance 03-30-2025 (w14) when all 3 weeks are fully observed.

> Info: Markdown run becomes eligible for compliance analysis on March 31, 2025, because this is when the full observation window â€” the forecast week and the two following weeks â€” has been completed.This eligibility logic is enforced through the procedure report.TrackComplianceRun, which calculates the EligibleDate for each RunId as: EligibleDate = DATEADD(WEEK, 3, ForecastStartDate)

## ðŸ§®4. Compliance Calculation Logic

This section explains how compliance is defined and measured for each item within a markdown run.

c

This section explains how compliance is defined and measured for each item within a markdown run.

### Discount Compliance (Fiba vs. Invent Decision)

We track whether a discount was applied by Fiba and/or Invent:

- Discount_Fiba = 1: If the price seen on customer side dropped enough compared to the initial price to say there is a discount:ROUND(1 - PriceFiba / InitialPrice, 2) >= PreviousDiscountRate + 0.03
OR WeekPrice >= PriceFiba * 1.03
- Discount_Invent = 1: If Invent recommends a discount at least 3 percentage points deeper than the previous week which means discount decision is made for this weekROUND(ProjectedDiscount, 2) >= ROUND(PreviousDiscountRate, 2) + 0.03

### Price Compliance Logic

Price compliance checks if the price recommended by Invent is actually reached by Fiba within a 3-week window (forecast week + 2).

The logic:

mended by Invent is actually reached by Fiba within a 3-week window (forecast week + 2).

The logic:

- We collect price history using ItemPrices and define weekly ranges using StartDate and Valid fields.
- If any price during the 3-week window falls within Â±5% of the recommended WeekPrice, we mark the item as compliant:ip.Price BETWEEN wp.WeekPrice * 0.95 AND wp.WeekPrice * 1.05
- This is evaluated for three rolling windows:

WeekStart (forecast week)

WeekStart + 1 week

WeekStart + 2 weeks

If any of these windows contain a price within range, then:

```
Compliance = 1
```

This ensures that even if client delays applying the price recommendation, it can still count as compliant â€” as long as it occurs within the observation period

## ðŸ“Š 5. Tableau Dashboard Integration

The `RunItemComplResults` table â€” generated and stored using `report.CreateComplianceReport` â€” serves as the data source for the Tableau dashboard.

The dashboard includes multiple layers of visibility:

as the data source for the Tableau dashboard.

The dashboard includes multiple layers of visibility:

- Compliance Matrix: A matrix breaking down whether discounts and price matches occurred â€” highlighting full, partial, or no compliance situations
- Compliance Ratio Table: A quick lookup for each RunId showing:Discount Compliance RatePrice Compliance Rate

> Info: Multi-run Insights:: When multiple runs are selected, Tableau dynamically recalculates and displays aggregated compliance ratios at the bottom. This helps users quickly assess overall compliance performance for a specific date range or subset of runs.

- Run-Based Summary: Aggregated stats per run, including counts of discounted and compliant items
- Item-Based Summary: Item-level breakdown with pricing details (Invent Price, Fiba Price, Initial Price, Discount calculations)

evel breakdown with pricing details (Invent Price, Fiba Price, Initial Price, Discount calculations)

[https://fiba.next.inventanalytics.com/reports/ComplianceReport/ComplianceReport](https://fiba.next.inventanalytics.com/reports/ComplianceReport/ComplianceReport)

## ðŸ› ï¸6. Manual Backfill and Testing

noteThe compliance pipeline is fully automated, but it also allows for manual backfills of historical runs.

The compliance pipeline is fully automated, but it also allows for manual backfills of historical runs.

### Manually Running CreateComplianceReport

You can run the compliance analysis for a specific `RunId` manually:

```
EXEC report.CreateComplianceReport @RunId = 1234;
```

This is especially useful when:

- You want to validate the logic for a specific case
- You need to get a compliance analysis for old runs

### Manually Running PendingComplianceRuns

To simulate the automated behavior for past runs, use:

```sql
EXEC report.TrackComplianceRun @RunId = 1234;
```

the automated behavior for past runs, use:

```sql
EXEC report.TrackComplianceRun @RunId = 1234;
```

You may run this for multiple historical runs before running the compliance evaluation:

```
EXEC report.ProcessEligibleComplianceRuns;
```

If you want to simulate the daily evaluation logic but control which runs are eligible:

```
DELETE FROM report.PendingComplianceRuns;

-- Insert only recent runs (example: last 1 month)
INSERT INTO report.PendingComplianceRuns (RunId, EligibleDate)
SELECT RunId, DATEADD(WEEK, 3, ForecastStartDate)
FROM markdown.RunWeeklyRateConstraints
WHERE ForecastStartDate >= DATEADD(MONTH, -1, GETDATE());

-- Then process them
EXEC report.ProcessEligibleComplianceRuns;
```

This section enables admins to:

- Backfill compliance results on demand
- Rerun analysis for missed or incorrect evaluations

## ðŸ§ 7. Best Practices & Troubleshooting

### âœ… Best Practices

s for missed or incorrect evaluations

## ðŸ§ 7. Best Practices & Troubleshooting

### âœ… Best Practices

- Ensure TrackComplianceRun is only called once per run â€” immediately after run completion via postprocess.
- Avoid running CreateComplianceReport manually unless for testing or backfill.
- Monitor PendingComplianceRuns to ensure no stuck or unprocessed runs.

### âš ï¸ Troubleshooting

- Duplicate insert errors: Usually caused by manually re-running the compliance SP for a run already processed. Check RunItemComplResults.
- Empty results: Ensure the run has valid price history (ItemPrices) for the full 3-week window.
- EligibleDate mismatch: Check that ForecastStartDate is accurate and DATEADD(WEEK, 3, ...) reflects true week alignment.

    IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#GrossMargin') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #GrossMargin;
    SELECT rip.RunId,
           rip.ItemCode,
           rip.StoreCluster,
           rip.MinDiscountRate AS GlobalMinDiscount,
           rip.MaxDiscountRate AS GlobalMaxDiscount,
           rop.ForecastStartStock,
           rip.SellThruTarget,
           rip.ExitDate,
           rop.weekstoexit,
           COALESCE(rip.MinGrossMargin, 0)                                 AS MinGrossMargin,
           rop.InitialPrice,
           rop.ScheduledPrice,
           rop.CostOfGoodsSold,
           1 - (rop.CostOfGoodsSold * 1.0 / NULLIF(rop.ScheduledPrice, 0)) AS CurrentGrossMargin
    INTO #GrossMargin
    FROM FibaDelta.markdown.RunItemParameters rip
             INNER JOIN #RecentOptimizationParameters rop
                        ON rip.ItemCode = rop.ItemCode

INNER JOIN #RecentOptimizationParameters rop

                            AND rop.ScheduledPrice > ips.PriceStep

    GROUP BY ips.ItemCode, ips.StoreCluster;

               WHEN ri.ItemCode IS NOT NULL THEN ri.Description
               WHEN iic.Age < 3 THEN 'Young product for discount (Age<21 day)'
               WHEN isi.ItemCode IS NOT NULL THEN isi.Explanation
               WHEN calc.WeekDiscountRate > calc.PreviousDiscountRate + 0.03
                   THEN 'The item has a discount'
               --WHEN calc.WeekDiscountRate <= calc.PreviousDiscountRate + 0.03
                   --THEN 'The item has no discount'
               WHEN calc.ForecastStartStock < 5
                   THEN 'Not enough stock level for discount (ForecastStartStock<5)'
               WHEN c.ItemCode IS NULL THEN 'The item has not entered into the calendar'
               WHEN (calc.SellthruTarget - calc.ST_Projection_0) < 0 THEN 'ST target already reached'
               WHEN calc.PreviousDiscountRate >= COALESCE(c.MaxDiscountRate, 1)
                   THEN 'The item has reached  max discount limit'

>= COALESCE(c.MaxDiscountRate, 1)

               WHEN nsc.NextDiscountRate > COALESCE(c.MaxDiscountRate, 1)

                   THEN 'Next price step exceeds the GM limit'
               ELSE 'Detailed review required'

INTO #Final
    FROM #ItemTargetGroups itg
             LEFT JOIN #Calendar c
                       ON c.ItemCode = itg.ItemCode
                           AND c.StoreCluster = itg.StoreCluster
             LEFT JOIN #NextStepCalculations nsc
                       ON itg.ItemCode = nsc.ItemCode
                           AND itg.StoreCluster = nsc.StoreCluster
             LEFT JOIN #Calculations calc
                       ON calc.ItemCode = itg.ItemCode
                           AND calc.StoreCluster = itg.StoreCluster
             LEFT JOIN FibaDelta.markdown.ItemInformationCache iic
                       ON iic.ItemCode = itg.ItemCode
                           AND iic.StoreCluster = itg.StoreCluster
             LEFT JOIN #OptimizationResults opr
                       ON opr.ItemCode = itg.ItemCode
                           AND opr.StoreCluster = itg.StoreCluster
             LEFT JOIN FibaDelta.markdown.InfeasibleSolverItems isi

.StoreCluster = itg.StoreCluster
             LEFT JOIN FibaDelta.markdown.InfeasibleSolverItems isi
                        ON itg.ItemCode = isi.ItemCode
                            AND itg.StoreCluster = isi.StoreCluster
                            AND isi.RunId = @RunId
             LEFT JOIN FibaDelta.markdown.RemovedItems ri
                        ON itg.ItemCode = ri.ItemCode
                            AND itg.StoreCluster = ri.StoreCluster
                            AND ri.RunId = @RunId
             LEFT JOIN #GrossMargin gi
                       ON itg.ItemCode = gi.ItemCode
                           AND itg.StoreCluster = gi.StoreCluster
                           AND gi.RunId = @RunId

    INSERT INTO FibaReporting.report.RunAnalysisReport
    SELECT * FROM #Final;

END;
go

```

### Tableau Connection

Tableau fetches live data from `RunAnalysisReport` via stored procedure `GetRunAnalysisReport`.

ion

Tableau fetches live data from `RunAnalysisReport` via stored procedure `GetRunAnalysisReport`.

```
CREATE PROCEDURE [report].[GetRunAnalysisReport]
@RunId INT = NULL
AS
BEGIN
    SET NOCOUNT ON;
    SELECT * FROM FibaReporting.report.RunAnalysisReport WHERE RunId = @RunId;
END

-- TABLES TO CHECK
-------------------
-- markdown.ItemInformationCache (GET ITEMS FOR THE SEASON)
-- markdown.MarkdownSeasons (GET SEASON BEGINNING AND END DATES)
-- markdown.ItemSeasonHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemEntryDates (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemPriceHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemDiscountSteps (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS WITH NO DEFINED STEPS)
-- markdown.ItemPriceSteps (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS WITH NO DEFINED STEPS)
-- markdown.WeeklyPastData (CHECK IF ITEM EXISTS FOR THE MOST RECENT WEEK)
-- markdown.ExternalForecasts (CHECK IF ITEM EXISTS IN THE FORECASTS)

ISTS FOR THE MOST RECENT WEEK)
-- markdown.ExternalForecasts (CHECK IF ITEM EXISTS IN THE FORECASTS)
-- data.InventoryPosition (CHECK MISSING ITEMS)
-- data.WarehouseInventoryPosition (CHECK MISSING ITEMS)

-- Get Season Information
SELECT *
FROM markdown.MarkdownSeasons
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId

-- 1. Check if item exists on ItemInformationCache
SELECT ItemCode,
       SeasonId,
       StoreCluster,
       Description,
       H1,
       H2,
       H3,
       Age,
       SizeCount
FROM markdown.ItemInformationCache
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
AND ItemCode = @ItemCode

--2. Check markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
SELECT *
FROM markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
  AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode

--3. Check markdown.ItemEntryDates
SELECT *
FROM markdown.ItemEntryDates
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
  AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode
ORDER BY EntryDate

  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode

--4. Check markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory
SELECT *
FROM markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory
WHERE Season = @SeasonId
  AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode
ORDER BY StartDate

--5. Check markdown.ItemPriceHistory
SELECT *
FROM markdown.ItemPriceHistory
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
  AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode
ORDER BY StartDate

--6. Check markdown.ItemPriceSteps
SELECT *
FROM markdown.ItemPriceSteps
WHERE StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode
ORDER BY StartDate DESC

--7. Check markdown.ItemDiscountSteps
SELECT *
FROM markdown.ItemDiscountSteps
WHERE StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode
ORDER BY StartDate DESC

-- 8. WeeklyPastData

metadata.title: Ipekyol Input Control Query (For Item Specific Analysis)

content:
toreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode
ORDER BY StartDate DESC

-- 8. WeeklyPastData

SELECT *
FROM markdown.WeeklyPastData
WHERE StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode
  AND WeekStartDate >= @SeasonBeginning
  AND WeekStartDate <= @SeasonEnd
ORDER BY WeekStartDate DESC

--9. ExternalForecasts

SELECT *
FROM markdown.ExternalForecasts
WHERE ItemCode = @ItemCode
AND StoreCluster= @StoreCluster
ORDER BY WeekStart, IsCurrentProjection DESC, WeekPrice

-- 10. InventoryPosition & WarehouseInventoryPosition

-- 10.0 Get InventoryPosition and WarehouseInventoryPosition extracts for the season

IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#IP') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #IP
SELECT *
INTO #IP
FROM data.InventoryPosition IP
WHERE IP.Date >= @SeasonBeginning AND IP.Date <= @SeasonEnd

IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#WIP') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #WIP
SELECT *
INTO #WIP
FROM data.WarehouseInventoryPosition WIP
WHERE WIP.Date >= @SeasonBeginning AND WIP.Date <= @SeasonEnd

content:
OM data.WarehouseInventoryPosition WIP
WHERE WIP.Date >= @SeasonBeginning AND WIP.Date <= @SeasonEnd

--10.1 Check data.InventoryPosition
SELECT *
FROM #IP IP
INNER JOIN markdown.ItemProductMatchings IPM ON IPM.ProductCode = IP.ProductCode
WHERE IPM.ItemCode = @ItemCode
ORDER BY IP.Date DESC

--10.2 Check data.WarehouseInventoryPosition
SELECT *
FROM #WIP WIP
INNER JOIN markdown.ItemProductMatchings IPM ON IPM.ProductCode = WIP.ProductCode
WHERE IPM.ItemCode = @ItemCode
ORDER BY WIP.Date DESC

content:
-- TABLES TO CHECK
-------------------
-- markdown.ItemInformationCache (GET ITEMS FOR THE SEASON)
-- markdown.MarkdownSeasons (GET SEASON BEGINNING AND END DATES)
-- markdown.ItemSeasonHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemEntryDates (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemPriceHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemDiscountSteps (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS WITH NO DEFINED STEPS)
-- markdown.ItemPriceSteps (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS WITH NO DEFINED STEPS)
-- markdown.WeeklyPastData (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS FOR SEASON RANGE)
-- data.InventoryPosition (CHECK MISSING ITEMS)

metadata.title: Mavi Input Control Query (For High Level Overview)

content:
eklyPastData (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS FOR SEASON RANGE)
-- data.InventoryPosition (CHECK MISSING ITEMS)
-- data.WarehouseInventoryPosition (CHECK MISSING ITEMS)
-- markdown.ExternalForecasts (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS)

-- GET SEASON ITEMS
IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#Items') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #Items
SELECT ItemCode,
       SeasonId,
       StoreCluster,
       Description,
       H1,
       H2,
       H3,
       Age,
       SizeCount
INTO #Items
FROM markdown.ItemInformationCache
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster

metadata.title: Mavi Input Control Query (For High Level Overview)

content:
Items
FROM markdown.ItemInformationCache
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster

--1. ITEMSEASONHISTORY
-------------------------
-- MISSING ITEMS ON markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
SELECT StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3,
       COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode) AS MissingItem_ISH
FROM #Items
WHERE ItemCode NOT IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode
                       FROM MaviV3.markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
                       WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
                         AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster)
GROUP BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3
ORDER BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3

metadata.title: Mavi Input Control Query (For High Level Overview)

content:
toreCluster)
GROUP BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3
ORDER BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3

-- DATE MISMATCH ON markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
SELECT IIC.StoreCluster, IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3,
       COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN IED.EntryDate < S.SeasonBeginningDate THEN IED.ItemCode END) AS DateMismatch_BeforeSeason_IED,
       COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN IED.EntryDate > S.SeasonEndDate THEN IED.ItemCode END) AS DateMismatch_AfterSeason_IED
FROM markdown.ItemEntryDates IED
INNER JOIN #Items IIC ON IIC.ItemCode = IED.ItemCode
                             AND IIC.StoreCluster = IED.StoreCluster
                             AND IIC.SeasonId = IED.SeasonId
LEFT JOIN markdown.MarkdownSeasons S ON IED.SeasonId = S.SeasonId
WHERE (IED.EntryDate < S.SeasonBeginningDate) OR (IED.EntryDate > S.SeasonEndDate)
GROUP BY IIC.StoreCluster, IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3
ORDER BY IIC.StoreCluster, IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3

content:
IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3
ORDER BY IIC.StoreCluster, IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3

--1. ITEMENTRYDATES
-------------------------
-- MISSING ITEMS ON markdown.ItemEntryDates
SELECT StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3,
       COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode) AS MissingItem_IED
FROM #Items

                       FROM markdown.ItemEntryDates
                       WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
                         AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster)
GROUP BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3
ORDER BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3

-- DATE MISMATCH ON markdown.ItemEntryDates
SELECT IIC.StoreCluster, IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3,
       COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN ISH.StartDate < S.SeasonBeginningDate THEN ISH.ItemCode END) AS DateMismatch_BeforeSeason_IED,
       COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN ISH.StartDate > S.SeasonEndDate THEN ISH.ItemCode END) AS DateMismatch_AfterSeason_IED
FROM markdown.ItemSeasonHistory ISH
INNER JOIN #Items IIC ON IIC.ItemCode = ISH.ItemCode
                             AND IIC.StoreCluster = ISH.StoreCluster
                             AND IIC.SeasonId = ISH.SeasonId
LEFT JOIN markdown.MarkdownSeasons S ON ISH.SeasonId = S.SeasonId
WHERE (ISH.StartDate < S.SeasonBeginningDate) OR (ISH.StartDate > S.SeasonEndDate)
GROUP BY IIC.StoreCluster, IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3
ORDER BY IIC.StoreCluster, IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3

       @SeasonEnd = SeasonEndDate

ingDate,
       @SeasonEnd = SeasonEndDate
FROM markdown.MarkdownSeasons
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId;

IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#itemseasonhistory') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #itemseasonhistory
SELECT *,  LEAD(StartDate, 1, GETDATE()) OVER (PARTITION BY ItemCode ORDER BY StartDate) AS Valid
INTO #itemseasonhistory
FROM markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
AND ItemCode IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode FROM #Items)

IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#itementrydates') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #itementrydates
SELECT *,  LEAD(EntryDate, 1, GETDATE()) OVER (PARTITION BY ItemCode ORDER BY EntryDate) AS Valid
INTO #itementrydates
FROM markdown.ItemEntryDates
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
AND ItemCode IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode FROM #Items)

metadata.title: Mavi Input Control Query (For High Level Overview)

content:
own.ItemEntryDates
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
AND ItemCode IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode FROM #Items)

SELECT WPD.WeekStartDate, COUNT(DISTINCT WPD.ItemCode) AS ItemCount
FROM markdown.WeeklyPastData WPD
INNER JOIN #Items IIC ON WPD.ItemCode = IIC.ItemCode
                      AND WPD.StoreCluster = IIC.StoreCluster
INNER JOIN #itemseasonhistory ISH ON WPD.ItemCode = ISH.ItemCode
    AND WPD.WeekStartDate >= ISH.StartDate AND WPD.WeekStartDate < ISH.Valid
INNER JOIN  #itementrydates IED ON WPD.ItemCode = IED.ItemCode
    AND WPD.WeekStartDate >= IED.EntryDate AND WPD.WeekStartDate < IED.Valid
WHERE WPD.StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
AND WPD.WeekStartDate >= @SeasonBeginning
AND WPD.WeekStartDate <= @SeasonEnd
GROUP BY WPD.WeekStartDate
ORDER BY WPD.WeekStartDate

DROP TABLE #itemseasonhistory
DROP TABLE #itementrydates

content:
InventoryPosition & WarehouseInventoryPosition
-----------------------------------------------------

-- Get InventoryPosition and WarehouseInventoryPosition extracts for the season
IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#IP') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #IP
SELECT *
INTO #IP
FROM data.InventoryPosition IP
WHERE IP.Date >= @SeasonBeginning AND IP.Date <= @SeasonEnd

IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#WIP') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #WIP
SELECT *
INTO #WIP
FROM data.WarehouseInventoryPosition WIP
WHERE WIP.Date >= @SeasonBeginning AND WIP.Date <= @SeasonEnd

-- MISSING ITEMS ON data.InventoryPosition
SELECT StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3,
       COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode) AS MissingItem_IP
FROM #Items
WHERE ItemCode NOT IN (SELECT DISTINCT IPM.ItemCode
                       FROM #IP IP
                       INNER JOIN markdown.ItemProductMatchings IPM ON IP.ProductCode = IPM.ProductCode)
GROUP BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3
ORDER BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3

       COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode) AS MissingItem_WIP
FROM #Items
WHERE ItemCode NOT IN (SELECT DISTINCT IPM.ItemCode
                       FROM #WIP WIP
                       INNER JOIN markdown.ItemProductMatchings IPM ON WIP.ProductCode = IPM.ProductCode)
GROUP BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3
ORDER BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3

DROP TABLE #IP
DROP TABLE #WIP

-- 7. ExternalForecasts
-----------------------------------------------------

SELECT WeekStart, IsCurrentProjection, COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode)
FROM markdown.ExternalForecasts
WHERE StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode FROM #Items)
GROUP BY WeekStart, IsCurrentProjection
ORDER BY WeekStart, IsCurrentProjection

DROP TABLE #Items

-- TABLES TO CHECK
-------------------
-- markdown.ItemInformationCache (GET ITEMS FOR THE SEASON)
-- markdown.MarkdownSeasons (GET SEASON BEGINNING AND END DATES)
-- markdown.ItemSeasonHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemEntryDates (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemPriceHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemDiscountSteps (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS WITH NO DEFINED STEPS)
-- markdown.ItemPriceSteps (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS WITH NO DEFINED STEPS)
-- markdown.WeeklyPastData (CHECK IF ITEM EXISTS FOR THE MOST RECENT WEEK)
-- markdown.ExternalForecasts (CHECK IF ITEM EXISTS IN THE FORECASTS)

-- markdown.ExternalForecasts (CHECK IF ITEM EXISTS IN THE FORECASTS)
-- data.InventoryPosition (CHECK MISSING ITEMS)
-- data.WarehouseInventoryPosition (CHECK MISSING ITEMS)

-- Get Season Information
SELECT *
FROM markdown.MarkdownSeasons
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId

-- 1. Check if item exists on ItemInformationCache
SELECT ItemCode,
       SeasonId,
       StoreCluster,
       Description,
       H1,
       H2,
       H3,
       Age,
       SizeCount
FROM markdown.ItemInformationCache
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
AND ItemCode = @ItemCode

--2. Check markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
SELECT *
FROM markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
  AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode

--3. Check markdown.ItemEntryDates
SELECT *
FROM markdown.ItemEntryDates
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
  AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode
ORDER BY EntryDate

  AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode

--5. Check markdown.ItemPriceHistory

WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
  AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode = @ItemCode

--6. Check markdown.ItemPriceSteps

--9. ExternalForecasts

INNER JOIN markdown.ItemProductMatchings IPM ON IPM.ProductCode = WIP.ProductCode
WHERE IPM.ItemCode = @ItemCode
ORDER BY WIP.Date DESC

-- TABLES TO CHECK
-------------------
-- markdown.ItemInformationCache (GET ITEMS FOR THE SEASON)
-- markdown.MarkdownSeasons (GET SEASON BEGINNING AND END DATES)
-- markdown.ItemSeasonHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemEntryDates (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemFirstPriceHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemPriceHistory (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS THAT DO NOT EXIST FOR THE SEASON OR HAVE A DATE MISMATCH WITH THE SEASON RANGE)
-- markdown.ItemDiscountSteps (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS WITH NO DEFINED STEPS)
-- markdown.ItemPriceSteps (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS WITH NO DEFINED STEPS)
-- markdown.WeeklyPastData (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS FOR SEASON RANGE)
-- data.InventoryPosition (CHECK MISSING ITEMS)

eklyPastData (CHECK COUNT OF ITEMS FOR SEASON RANGE)

-- GET SEASON ITEMS
IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#Items') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #Items
SELECT ItemCode,
       SeasonId,
       StoreCluster,
       Description,
       H1,
       H2,
       H3,
       Age,
       SizeCount
INTO #Items
FROM markdown.ItemInformationCache
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster

Items

AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster

--1. ITEMSEASONHISTORY
-------------------------
-- MISSING ITEMS ON markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
SELECT StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3,
       COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode) AS MissingItem_ISH
FROM #Items
WHERE ItemCode NOT IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode
                       FROM MaviV3.markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
                       WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
                         AND StoreCluster = @StoreCluster)
GROUP BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3
ORDER BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3

toreCluster)

-- DATE MISMATCH ON markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
SELECT IIC.StoreCluster, IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3,
       COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN IED.EntryDate < S.SeasonBeginningDate THEN IED.ItemCode END) AS DateMismatch_BeforeSeason_IED,
       COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN IED.EntryDate > S.SeasonEndDate THEN IED.ItemCode END) AS DateMismatch_AfterSeason_IED
FROM markdown.ItemEntryDates IED
INNER JOIN #Items IIC ON IIC.ItemCode = IED.ItemCode
                             AND IIC.StoreCluster = IED.StoreCluster
                             AND IIC.SeasonId = IED.SeasonId
LEFT JOIN markdown.MarkdownSeasons S ON IED.SeasonId = S.SeasonId
WHERE (IED.EntryDate < S.SeasonBeginningDate) OR (IED.EntryDate > S.SeasonEndDate)
GROUP BY IIC.StoreCluster, IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3
ORDER BY IIC.StoreCluster, IIC.SeasonId, IIC.H1, IIC.H2, IIC.H3

ingDate,

IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#itemseasonhistory') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #itemseasonhistory
SELECT *,  LEAD(StartDate, 1, GETDATE()) OVER (PARTITION BY ItemCode ORDER BY StartDate) AS Valid
INTO #itemseasonhistory
FROM markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
AND ItemCode IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode FROM #Items)

IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#itementrydates') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #itementrydates
SELECT *,  LEAD(EntryDate, 1, GETDATE()) OVER (PARTITION BY ItemCode ORDER BY EntryDate) AS Valid
INTO #itementrydates
FROM markdown.ItemEntryDates
WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId
AND ItemCode IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode FROM #Items)

own.ItemEntryDates

AND ItemCode IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode FROM #Items)

SELECT WPD.WeekStartDate, COUNT(DISTINCT WPD.ItemCode) AS ItemCount
FROM markdown.WeeklyPastData WPD
INNER JOIN #Items IIC ON WPD.ItemCode = IIC.ItemCode
                      AND WPD.StoreCluster = IIC.StoreCluster
INNER JOIN #itemseasonhistory ISH ON WPD.ItemCode = ISH.ItemCode
    AND WPD.WeekStartDate >= ISH.StartDate AND WPD.WeekStartDate < ISH.Valid
INNER JOIN  #itementrydates IED ON WPD.ItemCode = IED.ItemCode
    AND WPD.WeekStartDate >= IED.EntryDate AND WPD.WeekStartDate < IED.Valid
WHERE WPD.StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
AND WPD.WeekStartDate >= @SeasonBeginning
AND WPD.WeekStartDate <= @SeasonEnd
GROUP BY WPD.WeekStartDate
ORDER BY WPD.WeekStartDate

DROP TABLE #itemseasonhistory
DROP TABLE #itementrydates

content:
InventoryPosition & WarehouseInventoryPosition
-----------------------------------------------------

-- Get InventoryPosition and WarehouseInventoryPosition extracts for the season
IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#IP') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #IP
SELECT *
INTO #IP
FROM data.InventoryPosition IP
WHERE IP.Date >= @SeasonBeginning AND IP.Date <= @SeasonEnd

IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#WIP') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #WIP
SELECT *
INTO #WIP
FROM data.WarehouseInventoryPosition WIP
WHERE WIP.Date >= @SeasonBeginning AND WIP.Date <= @SeasonEnd

-- MISSING ITEMS ON data.InventoryPosition
SELECT StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3,
       COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode) AS MissingItem_IP
FROM #Items
WHERE ItemCode NOT IN (SELECT DISTINCT IPM.ItemCode
                       FROM #IP IP
                       INNER JOIN markdown.ItemProductMatchings IPM ON IP.ProductCode = IPM.ProductCode)
GROUP BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3
ORDER BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3

-- MISSING ITEMS ON data.WarehouseInventoryPosition
SELECT StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3,
       COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode) AS MissingItem_WIP
FROM #Items
WHERE ItemCode NOT IN (SELECT DISTINCT IPM.ItemCode
                       FROM #WIP WIP
                       INNER JOIN markdown.ItemProductMatchings IPM ON WIP.ProductCode = IPM.ProductCode)
GROUP BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3
ORDER BY StoreCluster, SeasonId, H1, H2, H3

DROP TABLE #IP
DROP TABLE #WIP

-- 7. ExternalForecasts
-----------------------------------------------------

SELECT WeekStart, IsCurrentProjection, COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode)
FROM markdown.ExternalForecasts
WHERE StoreCluster = @StoreCluster
  AND ItemCode IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode FROM #Items)
GROUP BY WeekStart, IsCurrentProjection
ORDER BY WeekStart, IsCurrentProjection

DROP TABLE #Items

       COUNT(DISTINCT
             CASE WHEN IED.EntryDate < S.SeasonBeginningDate THEN IED.ItemCode END)    AS DateMismatch_BeforeSeason_IED,
       COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN IED.EntryDate > S.SeasonEndDate THEN IED.ItemCode END) AS DateMismatch_AfterSeason_IED
FROM FloV2.markdown.ItemEntryDates IED

   OR (IED.EntryDate > S.SeasonEndDate)

This document explains the logic, implementation, and automation of a post-processing procedure that forcefully applies minimum discount rules to specific products in markdown runs marked with `_ZORUNLU`, bypassing forecast-based suppression and updating related reporting tables accordingly.

### 1. Purpose

When the client wants to enforce markdowns for a specific list of products based on minimum discount levels, they expect the system to apply these minimums regardless of expected performance. However, in practice, the optimization algorithm (based on GAMS) may determine that some products are unlikely to generate any sales even at the minimum discount level. In such cases, although the algorithm accepts the minimum discount as an input, it chooses not to apply any discountâ€”because it logically makes no difference in terms of forecasted revenue. This behavior makes sense from a model accuracy standpoint.

metadata.title: Post Process for Apply Forced Price Adjustment

content:
fference in terms of forecasted revenue. This behavior makes sense from a model accuracy standpoint.

However, there are business scenarios where the client intentionally wants to bypass this logic and enforce discounts manuallyâ€”either for communication, campaign uniformity, or vendor obligations. To support this, a post-processing layer was built.

However, some use cases require forcing these markdowns regardless of forecast logic. To support this, a post-process adjustment procedure was implemented. It does not alter the optimization output but overlays enforced prices on:

- Weekly item pricing (WeeklyProjection)
- Optimization results (OptimizationResults)
- Seasonal summaries (SeasonProjection)
- Analytical outputs (RunAnalysisReport)
-

### 2. Target Criteria

Adjustments are applied only to products meeting all of the following conditions:

metadata.title: Post Process for Apply Forced Price Adjustment

content:
. Target Criteria

Adjustments are applied only to products meeting all of the following conditions:

- The associated RunId has a UserComment that ends with _ZORUNLU
- ProjectionType = 0 (normal projection)
- Sales = 0 (no sales activity)
- FirstWeekDiscountRate = AdjustedWeekDiscountRate (no discount applied yet)
- FirstWeekDiscountRate < MinDiscountRate
- ForecastedSales = 0 (from RunAnalysisReport)
- InventNotes = 'Detailed review required' (from RunAnalysisReport)

### 3. Process Flow

#### Step 1: Identify Affected Items (#NoSalesProjections)

- Joins WeeklyProjection with RunWeeklyRateConstraints and RunAnalysisReport
- Filters only items flagged for review and with no forecasted sales
- Selects only the first week row (MIN WeekStart)

#### Step 2: Target Price Calculation (#PriceUpdates)

metadata.title: Post Process for Apply Forced Price Adjustment

content:
lects only the first week row (MIN WeekStart)

#### Step 2: Target Price Calculation (#PriceUpdates)

- Joins with RecentOptimizationParameters and RunItemParameters
- Calculates:TargetPrice = InitialPrice * (1 - MinDiscountRate)TargetPriceWithVat = InitialPriceWithVat * (1 - MinDiscountRate)
- Includes WeekPrice and WeekPriceWithVat as reference

#### Step 3: Closest Price Step Selection (#ClosestSteps)

- Uses ItemPriceSteps to find the closest available price step below or equal to the target
- Stores results as:NewScheduledPriceNewScheduledPriceWithVat

#### Step 4: Update Week 1 in WeeklyProjection

- Only rows with ROW_NUMBER() = 1 per item-store cluster are updated
- Fields updated:AdjustedWeekPriceAdjustedWeekPriceWithVatFirstWeekDiscountRateAdjustedWeekDiscountRate

#### Step 5: Update OptimizationResults

- Updates FirstWeekDiscountRate using the enforced price

#### Step 6: Update SeasonProjection

metadata.title: Post Process for Apply Forced Price Adjustment

content:
ults

- Updates FirstWeekDiscountRate using the enforced price

#### Step 6: Update SeasonProjection

- Fields updated:FirstWeekDiscountRateFirstWeekAdjustedDiscountRateFirstWeekAdjustedPriceFirstWeekAdjustedPriceWithVat

#### Step 7: Update RunAnalysisReport

- Fields updated:WeekDiscountRateNextPriceStepInventNotes = 'Enforced to follow the min rule'IsItemDiscounted = TRUE

| markdown.MarkdownRuns | Validates _ZORUNLU | RunId, UserComment |
| markdown.WeeklyProjection | Week-level prices | FirstWeekDiscountRate, AdjustedWeekDiscountRate, AdjustedWeekPrice, AdjustedWeekPriceWithVat |
| markdown.RecentOptimizationParameters | Initial price data | InitialPrice, InitialPriceWithVat, ScheduledPrice |
| markdown.RunItemParameters | Min discount constraints | MinDiscountRate |
| markdown.RunWeeklyRateConstraints | Week-specific discount limits | MinDiscountRate |
| report.RunAnalysisReport | Forecast and analysis outputs | ForecastedSales, InventNotes, WeekDiscountRate, NextPriceStep, IsItemDiscounted |

### 5. Automation Integration

This procedure is called inside `RunPostProcessQueries`, after the `CreateRunAnalysisReport` stored procedure is executedâ€”which populates the `RunAnalysisReport` table:

```
EXEC report.ApplyForcedPriceAdjustments @RunId = @RunId;
```

At the end of `ApplyForcedPriceAdjustments`, relevant records in the `RunAnalysisReport` table are updated with enforced pricing and discount information.

       COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode) AS MissingItem_ISH
FROM #Items
WHERE ItemCode NOT IN (SELECT DISTINCT ItemCode
                       FROM FibaDelta.markdown.ItemSeasonHistory
                       WHERE SeasonId = @SeasonId

       COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN IED.EntryDate < S.SeasonBeginningDate THEN IED.ItemCode END) AS DateMismatch_BeforeSeason_IED,
       COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN IED.EntryDate > S.SeasonEndDate THEN IED.ItemCode END) AS DateMismatch_AfterSeason_IED

INNER JOIN #Items IIC ON IIC.ItemCode = IED.ItemCode
